Award subject: Mineral and vitamin nutrition in grouper and tilapia aquaculture

The research I completed in Dr. Shi-Yen Shiau’s lab in National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) relates directly to his lab’s goal of investigating nutritional needs of important aquaculture fish, namely grouper and tilapia. Tilapia has already been recognized by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations as the most important protein-providing fish for human consumption of the 21st century. Grouper, although not currently cultured as extensively as tilapia, have the potential for large-scale culture due to their taste, rapid growth, and hardiness. Studying the nutritional requirements of these fish helps to advance their aquaculture and make it more efficient. By making aquaculture practices as efficient and environmentally responsible as possible, we can relieve fisheries pressure on wild populations. This practice can also produce fish year-round, generate much-needed jobs, raise a healthy food rich in protein and omega-3 fatty acids, and provide knowledge which could be used to enhance wild populations.

In the Shiau lab I participated in projects which tested the interaction of organic and inorganic copper sources with vitamin C in grouper, the optimal level of copper (organic) in tilapia feed, the interaction of manganese and vitamin C in grouper, and the dietary copper (organic) requirement of grouper. Trace minerals, such as copper, have been studied extensively for use in agriculture, but less work has been devoted to their use in aquaculture. In aquaculture, fish must obtain most of their required minerals from feeds, so a thorough understanding of their mineral requirements is essential for conserving cost of feed manufacture and minimizing the release of excess minerals into the environment. Copper, specifically, plays a key roll in the production of blood cells, and is a major structural component of essential enzymes. Organic minerals in agriculture, and now aquaculture, are emerging as possible substitutes for their inorganic counterparts. New research has indicated that their structure can make them easier for animals to uptake and utilize, less susceptible to the inhibitory action of other compounds, like fiber, and less soluble in water, lowering the likelihood of impacting the surrounding environment. Vitamin C cannot be created by fish, and thus is yet another nutrient that must be provided in the diet. This essential vitamin, however, has very different affects on the absorption of different minerals. Manganese is thought to be more readily absorbed with higher levels of vitamin C in the diet, but research with regard to this is lacking in fish. The mineral manganese is imperative for normal bone generation and nervous system function in fish. Research concerning each of these vitamins and minerals provides important information which can be immediately utilized by the aquaculture community.

During my time at the university, we hand-made each feed used for experimental diets. Besides other standard feed ingredients, the mineral or vitamin in question was added at different levels to the standard feed recipe in order to create experimental diets. When dietary mineral concentrations needed to be determined we frequently used flame atomic absorption photometry. I was also able to assist in some of the immunology and vitamin/mineral assessment work associated with processing the experimental fish used to test the interaction of organic versus inorganic copper sources with vitamin C.
